16:52 *hint “April showers bring May flowers”

Fun fact as to why your solar roof performs better in the spring: Just like batteries, solar panels also have a preferred temperature they operate at. The efficiency of solar panels is highest at 25 degrees Celsius (77F). When the Sun shines on the panels they might warm up beyond the ambient temperature, and in the summer this means that the performance and thus the yield is reduced. Whereas in spring the more moderate temperatures and sunny days mean that your panels at working at peak efficiency!
Wrong!!! the deeper the temperature the more efficient are the panels ! a cold morning in spring may even bring higher output than the named maximum !

@Marques Brownlee Thank you soo much for all the information, something to add is that the more perpendicular the solar panels are to the sun the more the panels will generate so the ratings the solar manufacture provided are correct, additionally photovoltaic panels use light energy from the sun and not the heat so ironically more heat makes them less efficient and more light makes them more efficient so you need them to dissipate the heat as quickly as possible. Fun thing is that my solar panels generate more energy on cooler days. Solar inventers tend to work better when its not that hot on a particular day.

Yep, I run solar at home, and May is the best month I get. The main reason for that is that the air is still cooler (compared to June/July/August) so the panels run at optimal performance. Solar panels do not like getting too hot, which is a bit of a silly thing. So in May there's plenty of sun, and the air is cooler. In July there's lots of sun but the panels are overheating all the time and are producing less.

Turns out May is very typically the best production month even though June is typically the most sunshine. Why? Temperature. Heat reduces efficiency in every electrical circuit (including solar cells), so the hotter your roof gets, the worse the efficiency of your solar system.

One thing to note, the sun might have much more power in the summer but the solar tiles heat up and are not as efficient anymore as they might be in spring when there is also a lot of sun but with milder temperatures which makes the solar systems much more efficient. Same applies to the battery of your car which operates best at around 70 to 80 degrees but if the summer days are too hot then the batteries are not as efficient anymore.

If the panel wattage is oversized compared to the inverters (which is the norm in Australia at least), you're probably not going to notice. May is the best month for my solar system as well (Moldova, Eastern Europe). Solar panels, as well as solar roof, "like" cold sunny weather - they perform better when outside is cold, in Summer, even if the days are longer but much warmer, solar panels do not produce so much electricity because they overheat.

One other reason your energy production peaked in May instead of the summer: solar panels become less efficient when they get hotter. So in peak summer they may collect less energy from the same sun-hours than in spring. Nonetheless a very interesting video!

Hey Marques! Thanks for the great video and explanation as always. Power R&D engineer here; I'm curious about any increase in efficiency of solar panels in colder months. Lower electron rest-levels at lower temperatures produce larger outputs per photon (could be up to 20% iirc!). This could explain the better overall performance in the spring (sunshine-temperature sweet-spot). Perhaps this can be confirmed by plotting outside temperatures on the same graph? Thanks again, lemme know what you think, and keep acing these videos :)

The summer solstice happens in june although july is a summer month so what would be expected to happen is a greater solar power production in june but as happens in mid june the solstice, may is like in the rear view mirror so the peak production may well happen in may , it will depend on lucky to have sunny days or not . Another thing that counts is that on high latitude places like New Jersey the sun rays are always tilted southward even around the midday so depending on your roof geometry and location the months around the solstice, i mean may to July , can actually have almost the same solar intensity because when your roof is tilted southward on its majority matching the sun rays direction the incidence will be high even on the early hours of the day because as you know due to the right ascension of the sun the solar rays are changing its direction every hour and the solar incidence lowers when the solar rays are too different of the roof’s inclination deflecting the majority of it.

16:29 I would have absolutely guessed April, May or June. Electronics don’t like heat and June 20th the the longest day of the year, so these effects lead to April-June being the best months for solar. March, July and August should also be kind of good. September and October get really cloudy and rainy and also dirty with all the leaves blowing around. In Germany we also use a lot of wind energy, so our electricity is cheap until November/early December with all the autumn storms. Autumn (I guess some call it Fall) is known for its strong winds (kids let their kites fly). But Germany, which is mostly north of the 50th parallel is pretty much f*ed from December to March. We used to burn Russian gas through turbines to produce energy, but that plan went to the toilet with Russias invasion of Ukraine (Also some of our supposed friends blew up our infrastructure, so that doesn’t help either; I am of course in complete support of Ukraine nonetheless). Plugging the chord on our nuclear plants was decided 2012, it was not possible to buy any new nuclear fuel (most of it is produced in Russia), so we just prolonged their run time till March and now we basically just have dirty coal for the next winter or extremely expensive LNG. We fought harder for renewables than any other country and now we are still completely f*ed over, that’s extremely depressing.

I'm in the middle of the video, where you talk about how may was your biggest net positive month. I am a meteorologist, and may 2023 in much of the northeast was either the sunniest may, or one of the sunniest mays on record. Also, this winter was a pretty warm winter overall for most of the US, so be prepared for most winters to be worse energy-wise (maybe not this winter though, a strong El Nino is forming, which tends to have relatively warm winters), than the previous.

May makes sense as the most solar collected. Note that it’s SOLAR COLLECTED, not “sunniest month”. If he wanted to collect the most solar on the longest, sunniest day, his panels should be less steeply angled. More information, solar panels are best angled at the same angle as the house’s latitude. So, you’ll optimizing your collection of solar in New Jersey if your panels are at a 40 degree angle, which will most likely occur for the longest times between March (cloudy) and May (sunny).
